speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "You have prepared the coffee"?

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez préparé le café?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "For me" in French is-

speaker: Marion
text: Pour moi.

speaker: Marion
text: Pour moi.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "You have prepared the coffee for me"?

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez préparé le café pour moi.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "You have" in French is-

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And this is a perfectly acceptable way to say, "You have," in French. However, as you may have noticed, it was also pronounced as-

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, the second pronunciation is the one more typically used by native French speakers. Although both are equally acceptable.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The, the basic reason why there's th- the, the two options for pronunciation is that in French, typically, the consonant at the end of a word won't be pronounced.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And so, the word for "you" in French is "vous", which is spelt V-O-U-S, and the S is, is not normally pronounced. However, for "you have", which in French is-

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The "have" begins with a vowel, with an 'a'. And so when a word follows it that begins with a vowel, you can if you want more or less push the 's' from the end of "vous" onto the vowel of the next one, "avez". And so you can make "vous avez" sound instead like-

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: This is entirely optional and up to you. So, what I would say is do what you're more comfortable with, but be aware at least that the French may well pronounce it as-

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Although if you want, you can also pronounce it as-

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: If you find it simpler to do so.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, uh, "for me" in French is-

speaker: Marion
text: Pour moi.

speaker: Marion
text: Pour moi.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "You have prepared the coffee for me"? Now, make sure when you're saying this to include all the components.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So you'll need, "You have prepared the coffee for me."

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez préparé le café pour moi.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, to turn that into a question, all you need to do is to, to change the order of the words "you have". So again, what, how would you say, "You have" in French?

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, let's turn that round and make it into a question, make it into "have you". How would you say, "Have you?"

speaker: Marion
text: Avez-vous?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "Have you prepared the coffee for me?"

speaker: Marion
text: Avez-vous préparé le café pour moi?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I have prepared roast beef for dinner. Have you prepared the coffee?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Let's start with that first bit with the, with, "I have prepared the roast beef for the dinner."

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai préparé le rosbif pour le dîner.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, make sure when you're saying "the dinner" in French that you pronounce it as-

speaker: Marion
text: Le dîner.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: That sort of 'ay' sound at the end of it.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Good. And the next part, "Have you prepared the coffee?"

speaker: Marion
text: Avez-vous préparé le café?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Thank you.
